msContents.summary: The Pañcarakṣā "Five Protections" consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī. The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit collection, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. This manuscript in black paper (nīlapatra), to be dated to the 17th or 18th century, bears illuminated wood covers with representations of the five goddesses and the five Buddhas.

msItem.title: Pañcarakṣā
msItem.incipit: [1v1] evam mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavān mahāvajrameruśikharakūṭāgāre viharati sma || mahāvajrasamādhibhūmipratiṣṭhāne | ma[1v2]-1-vajrakalpasamalaṃkṛte |

supportDesc.foliation: Rañjanā numerals, mid-right margin, verso (folio number 13 is wrongly foliated as 4. Many numerals are damaged and illegible).
Arabic numerals, top right corner, verso.
supportDesc.condition: Complete, in poor condition. Often frayed on the margins. The text is sometimes smudged and illegible, especially in the last folios. In some folios the layers of paper are falling off.

layoutDesc.layout:
4.5 25.5
The written area is smaller than that demarcated by the frame.
6 lines per page, approximately 60 akṣaras per line.
6
1
Two string holes approximately in the middle of square blank spaces.
1.8 1.8 9.5
Double marginal frame lines, or two pairs thereof, in golden ink. The dark-blue writing frame is framed by a marginal area in light blue.

decoNote.desc:
Both inner covers bear polichrome miniatures.
On the inner side of the back cover (which was originally the front cover), representations of the five Buddhas of directions (Ratnasambhava in yellow; Akṣobhya in blue; Vairocana in white; Amitābha in red; Amoghasiddhi in green).
On the inner side of the front cover (which was originally the back cover), representations of the five goddesses invoked for protection in the text, with colours matching the five Buddhas of directions.

history.provenance:
Presented by Mrs. E.K. Waterhouse Waterhouse, E. K.
in 1957.
